title: 113_hr4496
content: The Act is titled the "Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" and establishes universal access programs to improve high-risk pools and reinsurance markets for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. States without a current high-risk pool must establish one to meet the requirement. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish a qualified State reinsurance program to meet the requirement. States already operating a high-risk pool as of the enactment date will be treated as meeting the requirement. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish a qualified State reinsurance program. States already operating a high-risk pool will be treated as meeting the requirement. If the program or pool is in strong fiscal health, funds can be applied accordingly. A qualified State reinsurance program, as defined in the section, provides reinsurance for health insurance in the small group market. The program can operate on a prospective or retrospective basis and must meet fiscal health standards approved by the State Insurance Commissioner. A qualified State reinsurance program can provide reinsurance on a prospective or retrospective basis, protecting health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending and catastrophic costs. It must also satisfy HIPAA requirements and offer at least two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan with a health savings account. The current section describes the requirements for a qualified high-risk pool, including providing two coverage options, stable funding, no waiting lists, coverage for individuals in the disability waiting period, and limiting premiums to 150% of the average standard risk rates in the State. The high-risk pool must limit premiums to 150% of average rates, provide education on eligibility, cover preventive services, and verify citizenship for participation. The provision of law states that only US citizens and nationals can participate in a qualifying State high-risk pool receiving funds under specific sections. States must certify that applicants provide citizenship documentation. The Secretary keeps records for citizenship verification. Starting January 1, 2015, pools must meet certain criteria to qualify as high-risk pools. The Secretary must maintain records for citizenship verification, and starting January 1, 2015, high-risk pools must meet specific criteria to qualify. The Secretary has the authority to waive requirements for innovative programs, and additional funding is allocated for the Public Health Service Act. The Public Health Service Act allocates $15 billion for fiscal years 2015-2024 and an additional $10 billion for fiscal years 2020-2024. Definitions include terms like "health insurance coverage" and "Secretary." The term "qualified high risk pool" is defined under section 2745(g) of the Public Health Service Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "standard risk rate" is a rate determined in State high risk pools based on premium rates, actuarial techniques, and anticipated claims. "State" refers to any of the 50 States or the District of Columbia.
